Xi Jinping:
Xi Jinping is a prominent Chinese politician and the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China.  He has been leading China since March 2013, serving as the President of the People's Republic of China, Chairman of the Central Military Commission, and General Secretary of the Communist Party of China. 

He was born on June 15, 1953, into a political family in China.  His father, Xi Zhongxun, was a prominent communist politician.  Xi Jinping received his education in schools and universities in China, and later studied Agricultural Science at Tsinghua University. 

Xi Jinping has had a long career in Chinese politics.  He was the Governor of Fujian Province from 2000 to 2002, and the Secretary of the Communist Party of Zhejiang Province from 2002 to 2007.  During his time in these two provinces, Xi Jinping made efforts to promote economic development and fight against corruption. 

He was then transferred to be the Secretary of the Shanghai Municipal Party Committee in 2007, before being moved to Beijing in 2008 to become the Vice President of China.  In 2012, he was presented as the Successor to the Presidency of China. 

Upon assuming office as President, Xi Jinping launched a campaign to control corruption and strengthen discipline within the Communist Party of China.  This campaign has been unprecedented in China's history, leading to the removal of many high-level leaders on corruption charges. 

Xi Jinping has strengthened his influence within the Communist Party and government through several constitutional and policy amendments.  In 2018, at the Chinese Communist Party Congress, the constitution was amended to remove the two-term limit for the presidency, thereby allowing him to remain in office beyond his second term. 

Additionally, Xi Jinping has taken a tough stance in China's foreign policy, emphasizing the importance of China assuming a greater role in international affairs.  He has also enhanced China's relations with other countries by investing in infrastructure and trade projects through his "Belt and Road Initiative". 

Xi Jinping is seen by some as charismatic and powerful, known for his slogans "China's Dream" and "China's Revival".  However, there have also been concerns about the increasing government control under his leadership and the suppression of human rights in China.
Narendra Modi:
Narendra Modi is an Indian politician who was born on September 17, 1950.  He has been serving as the Prime Minister of India since May 2014.  Modi is a member of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which is a right-wing political party in India. 

Modi was born into a traditional Hindu family and grew up in the state of Gujarat, India.  Before entering politics, he worked as a tea stall owner.  Modi joined the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist organization, and later became actively involved in the political activities of the BJP. 

Modi served as the Chief Minister of the state of Gujarat for three different terms (2001-2014) before being elected as the Prime Minister of India.  He was credited for his work in the economic development and infrastructure of the state. 

As Prime Minister, Modi has made significant efforts to promote economic development, combat corruption, promote environmental cleanliness, and take measures for national security.  He has also continued to strengthen India's relations with other countries through diplomatic visits and trade agreements. 

However, there has been controversy and significant debate about Modi's government.  His opponents have raised allegations of increasing suppression of freedom of expression, religious discrimination against Muslims and other minorities, and actions inconsistent with human rights. 

Narendra Modi has gained significant popularity in India and internationally.  He has been elected as Prime Minister for two consecutive terms since 2014, ensuring strong control of his party and receiving support from many Indian citizens.
Joko Widodo:
Joko Widodo, popularly known as Jokowi, is a renowned politician and the current president of Indonesia.  He was born on June 21, 1961 in Surakarta, Central Java, Indonesia. 

Jokowi started his career as a businessman and a owner of a furniture shop before venturing into politics.  He gained popularity as the mayor of Solo city (Surakarta) from 2005 to 2012, where he implemented several development reforms and improved the city's infrastructure. 

In 2012, Jokowi entered national politics when he won the election for the governor of Jakarta province.  He served as the governor of Jakarta from 2012 to 2014 and worked closely with the city residents to improve public services such as education, healthcare, and transportation. 

In the presidential election of 2014, Jokowi was elected as the president of Indonesia after receiving more votes than his opponent.  He became the first Indonesian president with no political or military background. 

Since taking office, Jokowi has made significant efforts to enhance the economy and national development.  He has introduced reforms in the education, health, infrastructure, and agriculture sectors to increase economic opportunities for the people of Indonesia.  He has also initiated infrastructure projects such as railway and road construction to connect various parts of the country. 

Jokowi is also known for his dedication to combatting corruption and serving the poor.  He has been striving to improve governance and ensure transparency in the government. 

Jokowi has gained popularity as a leader close to the people and has become widely popular among the youth and voters.  He continues to be a prominent politician in the Asian region and has contributed to strengthening Indonesia's relations with other countries worldwide. 

Overall, Jokowi is recognized as a leader with good intentions and efforts to improve the lives of the people of Indonesia, and he has been making great efforts to bring development and positive changes to the nation.
Mamnoon Hussain:
Mamnoon Hussain was the twelfth President of Uzbekistan from 2013 to 2018.  He was born on December 23, 1940, in the city of Agra, India.  After the partition of India and Pakistan in 1947, his family moved to Karachi, Pakistan. 

Hussain studied commerce at the University of Karachi, where he obtained a bachelor's degree.  Later, he established his printing and plastic products distribution business. 

He joined the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) political party in 1970.  It was during this time that he started working with the famous politician and former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.  Hussain served as the president of the business wing in PML-N and also as the president of the youth wing of the party. 

In 1999, when the military removed Nawaz Sharif from power in a coup, Hussain faced strict laws and was briefly detained.  After his release, he continued to be involved in the country's politics. 

Hussain was appointed as the President of Uzbekistan after being elected by a panel of representatives in accordance with the country's constitution, which combines the presidential position with parliament elections.  He was the twelfth President of Uzbekistan and served for only one term until 2018 when his term ended. 

During his tenure as president, Mamnoon Hussain advocated for strengthening relations with other nations and promoting economic cooperation.  He worked to position Uzbekistan as a hub for trade and investment in the South Asian region. 

Mamnoon Hussain was known for being a moderate and prudent leader.  He was a religious person and advocated for Islamic principles.  He respected the constitution and laws of the country and strove to promote economic and social development. 

After completing his term as president, Hussain retired from politics and lives a quiet life.  He is a father of four and continues to engage in social activities and volunteering.
Sheikh Hasina:
Sheikh Hasina is a politician from Bangladesh and the chairperson of the Awami League party.  She was born on 28th September 1947 in Tungipara, Gopalganj district, Bangladesh.  Hasina is the daughter of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, who was the first President of Bangladesh, and Begum Fazilatunnessa Mujib, a political activist. 

Sheikh Hasina started her political career at a very young age, participating in the liberation movement of Bangladesh from the rule of Pakistan.  After the establishment of Bangladesh as an independent nation in 1971, Hasina began to build her reputation as a strong politician and a public leader. 

Hasina has served as the Prime Minister of Bangladesh twice, first from 1996 to 2001, and then again from 2009 to the present.  Her leadership has been successful, and she has been able to lead the country through economic changes and improve social welfare. 

During her leadership, Hasina has made efforts to reduce poverty and increase job opportunities for the people of Bangladesh.  She has been advocating for women's rights and has worked towards gender equality in various aspects of national life. 

Additionally, Hasina has been at the forefront of addressing environmental issues.  She has taken several steps to protect and conserve the environment, including banning plastic bags and safeguarding forests and natural areas. 

Sheikh Hasina has also shown her leadership in international diplomacy.  She has been fostering good relations with various countries worldwide and has helped Bangladesh receive financial and developmental aid from international partners. 

Overall, Sheikh Hasina is a powerful politician and a visionary leader.  She has made significant efforts to improve the standard of living for the people of Bangladesh and has strengthened Bangladesh's position on the international stage.  Sheikh Hasina continues to be a prominent and influential politician in Bangladesh and globally.
Shinzo Abe:
Shinzo Abe is a Japanese politician who served as the Prime Minister of Japan twice.  He led the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) and served as the Prime Minister of Japan from 2006 to 2007, and again from 2012 to 2020. 

He is known for his economic policy known as "Abenomics".  This policy aimed to promote economic growth in Japan through monetary policy, budget policy, and economic reforms.  Abe also aimed to strengthen Japan's military role and make changes to the Japanese Constitution to allow Japan to engage more in military activities. 

Abe had a difficult relationship with Japan's neighboring countries, such as South Korea and China, due to historical conflicts, especially the issue of World War II memorials.  However, he had a good relationship with the United States and built a close relationship with US President Donald Trump. 

Abe abruptly resigned in August 2020 citing health reasons.  He had been struggling with health issues related to his intestines, and stated that he would resign to seek further treatment.  After his resignation, Yoshihide Suga took over as the Prime Minister of Japan. 

Shinzo Abe has been a prominent figure in Japanese politics and has made a significant impact on his country.  He has worked to restore Japan's international status and strengthen the country's economy.
Benigno Aquino III:
Benigno Simeon Cojuangco Aquino III, popularly known as Noynoy Aquino, was the sixth President of the Republic of the Philippines.  He was the son of former Philippine President, Corazon Aquino, and former Senator Benigno Aquino Jr.  He held office from 2010 to 2016. 

Aquino was born on February 8, 1960 in Manila, Philippines.  He received his primary education at Ateneo de Manila School and later studied Economics at the University of the Philippines and Ateneo de Manila University. 

After graduating, Aquino worked in the business and economics sector for a while before entering politics.  He joined the Philippine House of Representatives in 1998 and served as a representative of Tarlac province until 2007.  He was later appointed as a senator in 2007 and served until 2010. 

Aquino was known for advocating democracy and human rights in the Philippines.  He was a member of the country's second-largest party, Kilusang Bagong Lipunan (New Society Movement), before joining the Liberal Party, of which his grandfather, Benigno Aquino Jr. , was also a member. 

In 2010, Aquino ran for presidency and won by a landslide.  One of his priorities was to fight corruption and bring about economic reforms in the Philippines.  He worked towards changing the legal, health, and education systems.  He also aimed to strengthen relations with other countries and increase economic and technological cooperation. 

However, Aquino's administration faced many challenges, including fighting Islamist terrorists and dealing with the aftermath of storms and the Typhoon Haiyan disaster.
Tr\u01b0\u01a1ng T\u1ea5n Sang:
Trương Tấn Sang is a Vietnamese politician who was born on January 21, 1949, in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.  He served as the president of Vietnam from 2011 to 2016. 

Trương Tấn Sang began his involvement in politics in the 1960s and 1970s when he joined the national liberation movement.  He joined the Communist Party of Vietnam (VCP) in 1967 and dedicated himself to the Vietnam War as a military officer and party assistant. 

After the war, Sang engaged in political affairs and rose through the ranks of the VCP leadership.  He served as the party secretary in Ho Chi Minh City and later became a member of the VCP Central Committee in 1996. 

In 2011, Trương Tấn Sang was elected as the president of Vietnam after defeating the incumbent candidate, Nguyễn Minh Triết.  During his presidency, Sang led several political and economic reforms in Vietnam.  He advocated for economic reform policies, foreign investment, and international cooperation, aiming to improve the country's economy and enhance Vietnam's position in the international community. 

Sang also continued to strengthen Vietnam's relations with other countries, especially in Asia and the West.  He spearheaded efforts to enhance economic and political cooperation with China, the United States, Japan, and other nations.  Additionally, he worked towards resolving border disputes with neighboring countries such as China and Cambodia. 

After completing his five-year term as president, Trương Tấn Sang retired from politics in 2016.  He was a key leader of Vietnam during a transitional period and guided the country through economic and political changes.
Recep Tayyip Erdo\u011fan:
Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is a prominent politician and the current president of Turkey.  He was born on February 26, 1954 in Istanbul, Turkey.  Erdoğan received his primary and secondary education in Islamic faith schools.  After completing his primary education, he entered the Istanbul Commerce University where he graduated in 1981. 

As a young man, Erdoğan joined Islamic beliefs and politics.  He was a member of the Welfare Party of Turkey (RP) which had a strict religious stance.  However, the party was banned by the Turkish government in 1997 and Erdoğan was arrested and imprisoned for 4 months for inciting hatred in a speech. 

After his release from prison, Erdoğan founded the Justice and Development Party (AKP) in 2001.  The party won the general elections in 2002 and Erdoğan became the first prime minister from an Islamic party in Turkey.  His leadership was known for promoting social and economic reforms, as well as emphasizing Islamic values. 

Erdoğan served as the prime minister of Turkey for 11 years, until he was elected as the president of the country in 2014.  He continued the reforms he had started as prime minister and continued to emphasize Islamic values and strengthen the country's economy.  His government has also faced controversy and opposition from politicians and human rights activists over allegations of curbing freedom of expression and political solutions. 

Erdoğan has been a strong leader who deeply loves Turkey and its policies.  He has led Turkey through significant political, economic, and social changes.  However, he has many supporters as well as many critics who seek further democratic reforms and freedom of expression.
Hassan Rouhani:
Hassan Rouhani is a politician from Iran who served as the President of Iran from 2013 to 2021.  He was born on November 12, 1948 in the city of Sorkheh, Iran. 

Rouhani began his involvement in politics at a young age and participated in the Iranian Islamic Revolution movement.  He studied law at the University of Tehran and later obtained his master's and doctoral degrees in law from the University of Glasgow, Scotland. 

He began his political and administrative career in the 1970s.  He was a member of the Islamic Society Party (IRP), which opposed the Shah's regime.  After the Iranian Islamic Revolution in 1979, Rouhani was appointed Deputy Minister of Defense and served in that position until 1983. 

Rouhani was widely known for his contribution to Iran's nuclear program.  He was the Head of Iran's National Security Council and the Head of the Nuclear Energy Negotiation Team, which led to the Iran nuclear agreement with world powers in 2015.  The agreement aimed to lift economic sanctions against Iran related to its nuclear program. 

Rouhani was elected President of Iran in 2013 and took office with promises to revive the country's economy and strengthen relations with foreign nations.  He sought reforms and changes in domestic and foreign policies and expressed his intention to relax some strict religious laws.  However, his efforts were overshadowed by many challenges, including hostility with the Donald Trump administration in the United States. 

Rouhani left office in 2021 after completing two terms in leadership.  He leaves behind a legacy of political and economic controversy but continues to be a key player in Iranian politics.
Prayut Chan-o-cha:
Prayut Chan-o-cha is a Thai politician who was born on March 21, 1954 in Nakhon Ratchasima, Thailand.  He was the head of the Thai military before becoming the prime minister of the country in 2014. 

Prayut studied at Chulachomklao Royal Military Academy and graduated with a teaching degree from Sripatum Law College.  He has received further training in the United States, China, and Germany. 

Before becoming the military chief, Prayut participated in the Vietnam War as the commander of a chemical defense unit and a helicopter assault unit.  He advanced in the military and held various leadership positions. 

In 2014, he led a military coup against the elected government of Yingluck Shinawatra.  After the coup, Prayut was appointed as the prime minister and leader of the interim government. 

Prayut has promised to protect Thailand's security and implement political and economic reforms in the country.  He has also promised to restore political stability to the nation, which has been embroiled in political conflicts for decades. 

However, Prayut's rule has faced significant criticism from his opponents and human rights organizations.  They have said that he has violated human rights and suppressed opposition.  There are also concerns about democracy and freedom of expression under his rule. 

Overall, Prayut Chan-o-cha is a controversial politician who continues to hold a leadership position in Thailand.  The future of his tenure and how history will remember him remains uncertain.
Thein Sein:
Thein Sein was a politician from Myanmar who served as the President of the country from 2011 to 2016.  He was born on April 20, 1945 in Kyonku, Myingyan, Myanmar. 

Sein began his political involvement in the 1960s and 1970s as a member of the Myanmar Workers' Party.  After the military regime was overthrown in 1988, he joined the Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP), the ruling party at that time. 

From 2007 to 2011, Sein served as the Prime Minister of Myanmar under the military regime.  He was known for implementing limited economic and political reforms, including opening up the country's economy and engaging more with the international community. 

In 2011, Sein was elected as the President of Myanmar for a five-year term.  Although his administration continued to make several reforms, it was also criticized for backtracking on democracy, failing to end religious violence, and continuing to persecute political opponents. 

After completing his first term, Sein decided not to run for re-election and instead lost his popularity in Myanmar politics.  However, after leaving office, he has continued to be a respected politician and still contributes to the country's political process.
Park Geun-hye:
Park Geun-hye is a South Korean politician who was the President of the country from 2013 to 2017.  She was the first woman to hold the presidency in South Korea. 

She was born on February 2, 1952, as the daughter of former South Korean President Park Chung-hee.  She grew up in a politically influential family, and thus was close to politics from a young age. 

Park started engaging in politics at a young age and participated in her father's political campaigns.  She was also the deputy head of a military group known as the "Council of the Mothers" which aimed to raise awareness about authoritarian rule. 

In politics, Park was a prominent member of the conservative Saenuri Party, which represented conservative views and free trade policies. 

When she was elected President of South Korea in 2013, she began implementing her policies including strengthening her country's relations with the United States and Japan, controlling nuclear issues in North Korea, and boosting the domestic economy. 

However, her administration faced a major corruption scandal and allegations of interference in government affairs on behalf of her close friend, Choi Soon-sil.  Public support for Park declined significantly and she was ultimately impeached in 2017 through a constitutional removal process that sparked large-scale protests in South Korea. 

After being removed from office, she faced corruption charges, trials were initiated against her and she was ultimately sentenced to 24 years in prison and fined 17 million dollars. 

Park Geun-hye remains the first South Korean President to be impeached through a legal constitutional process, and to this day, she continues to wield significant political influence in the country.
Fuad Masum:
Fuad Masum was an Iraqi politician who served as the country's president from 2014 to 2018.  He was born on January 1, 1938 in the city of Koya, Northern Iraq. 

Masum received his education at the University of Baghdad, where he obtained his first degree in law.  Later, he studied at the University of Cairo in Egypt, where he earned a master's degree in international law. 

From 1968 to 1973, Masum served at the University of Sulaimaniya as a law lecturer.  After that, he joined the University of Baghdad and taught in the law department. 

In the 1990s, Masum joined the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK), a political party representing the Kurdish people in Iraq.  He was a key member of the party and held various positions, including head of the foreign department and vice chairman of the party. 

Masum was a prominent and influential politician in the Kurdistan region and Iraq as a whole.  He was also an advocate for peace, peaceful conflict resolution, and Kurdish freedom. 

In 2014, Masum was appointed as the president of Iraq, taking over from the ailing Jalal Talabani.  His presidency was a challenging time for the country, which was facing the threat of the terrorist group ISIS and political unrest.  He utilized his authority and engaged all parties to bring peace and stability to Iraq. 

After completing his four-year term, Masum stepped down and handed over the presidency to the new Iraqi president, Barham Salih, in 2018.  After leaving office, Masum continued to be involved in Iraqi politics, contributing to peace and development in the country. 

Fuad Masum is a well-known Iraqi politician and advocate for justice and peace.  He is a respected leader who served his country with loyalty and dedication.
Ashraf Ghani:
Ashraf Ghani is a politician and economist from Afghanistan.  He was born on May 19, 1949, in Kabul and served as the President of Afghanistan from 2014 to 2021.  Ghani received his university education in Afghanistan and later studied at universities in France and the United States.  He was a chief advisor to the president on economic matters before becoming president. 
During his tenure as president, Ghani faced numerous challenges, including poverty, corruption, and the threat of the Taliban.  However, his administration faced significant opposition and in August 2021, he was forced to resign and flee the country after the Taliban captured the capital city of Kabul.  Ghani sought refuge in the United Arab Emirates. 
It is important to note that opinions on Ghani and his administration are varied and can differ depending on the observer's perspective.
Salman of Saudi Arabia:
Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has been the king of Saudi Arabia since January 2015.  He was born on December 31, 1935 in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.  He was the son of Ibn Saud, the founder of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and its first royal ruler. 

Salman began to establish himself politically from a young age and participated in the governance of the country as a horse rider and regional governor.  Later, he was appointed as the governor of Riyadh in the 1960s and served as the Minister of Defense of Saudi Arabia from 2011 to 2015. 

After the death of King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia in January 2015, Salman was appointed as the king.  He had the responsibility of leading Saudi Arabia at a time when the country faced many challenges, including the global decline in oil prices, the war in Yemen, and regional tensions. 

Salman has led several political, economic, and social initiatives during his reign.  He has made several changes in the government and advanced reform policies as part of the Saudi Vision 2030.  The vision aims to bring about economic and social reforms by reducing dependence on oil and developing other sectors. 

King Salman has also been praised for his efforts to foster relationships with other countries, including making official diplomatic visits to various nations worldwide.  He has sought to strengthen economic, political, and security cooperation with other nations. 

However, Salman's reign has also faced criticism for opposing human rights and freedom of expression in Saudi Arabia.  There are reports of human rights violations, political opposition suppression, and lack of press freedom in the country. 

Overall, Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud has made his mark in Saudi Arabia's history as a king focusing on economic development and strengthening relationships with other nations.  However, there are still many challenges that need to be addressed during his reign, especially concerning human rights and freedom of expression.
Islam Karimov:
Islam Karimov was a Uzbekistani politician who served as the President of Uzbekistan from 1991 until his death in September 2016.  He was born on January 30, 1938 in Samarkand, in the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic. 

Karimov studied law and economics at Tashkent University and excelled in his studies.  After graduating, he started his career in the field of economics and eventually gained fame as a good economist. 

In 1989, he was appointed as the Chairman of the Communist Party of Uzbekistan, and a year later, Uzbekistan gained independence from the Soviet Union.  In the first presidential election held in 1991, Karimov won and became the first President of Uzbekistan. 

During his rule, Karimov was known for his harsh rule and violation of human rights.  His government was known for suppressing political opposition and media freedom, and for imprisoning and persecuting many political opponents.  However, he was able to control Uzbekistan's economy and ensure political stability in the region. 

Karimov remained the President of Uzbekistan until his death on September 2, 2016, after suffering a stroke.  He was buried with great honor and the Uzbekistani government continued his authoritarian rule under the new President Shavkat Mirziyoyev.  Despite the controversy surrounding his rule, Karimov was a national hero to a part of Uzbekistan and he saw two generations of Uzbekistanis.
Najib Razak:
Najib Razak is a Malaysian politician who served as the Prime Minister of the country from 2009 to 2018.  He was born on July 23, 1953, into a political family; his father, Abdul Razak Hussein, was also a Prime Minister of Malaysia.  

Najib studied economics at the University of Nottingham in the United Kingdom.  After graduating, he joined the oil company Petronas and worked in the economic analysis department.  Later, he decided to enter politics and joined the ruling party, the United Malays National Organization (UMNO). 

Najib entered national politics in 1976 when he was elected as the Member of Parliament for Pekan.  He performed well and held various government positions, including Minister of Youth and Sports, Minister of Culture, Arts and Heritage, Minister of Transport, and Minister of Education. 

Najib was appointed as the Prime Minister of Malaysia in 2009 following the resignation of his predecessor, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi.  He was the first leader in the history of Malaysia whose father had also been a Prime Minister of the country. 

Najib's administration was marred by several corruption scandals, including the 1MDB corruption scandal.  An investigation report alleged that over $4. 5 billion were embezzled from the 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) company, which was established by Najib himself.  Additionally, he faced accusations of misusing public funds and tax evasion. 

In May 2018, Najib lost the general election and eventually resigned as Prime Minister.  Later, he was arrested and charged with multiple counts of corruption.  His case is still ongoing in the Malaysian courts.
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi:
Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi is a politician from Yemen who was born on September 1, 1945 in Thukain, Abyan District.  Hadi served as the President of South Yemen from 1994 to 2012, and he took over as the President of Yemen after Ali Abdullah Saleh resigned in 2012. 

Hadi received his education in the United Kingdom, where he graduated with a degree in modern engineering.  After completing his studies, he returned to Yemen and worked in the South Yemen Army Department. 

Hadi became more prominent in Yemeni politics after the unification of North and South Yemen in 1990.  Following the division and civil war in 1994, Hadi was elected Vice President of South Yemen. 

After Saleh resigned in 2012 and handed over power to Hadi, he began implementing several reforms in Yemen's political system.  However, Hadi faced many challenges, including attacks by the Houthi rebels and the terrorist group al-Qaeda. 

In 2014, the Houthis, most of whom are Shia, seized many areas in Yemen, including the capital, Sana'a.  Hadi and his government were forced to flee and relocate to the city of Aden, where he continued efforts to strengthen his government. 

In March 2015, Saudi Arabia and its allies decided to intervene militarily in Yemen to assist and restore Hadi to power.  However, the situation in Yemen has remained fragile and a permanent solution has yet to be found. 

Throughout his presidency, Hadi has been striving to strengthen the authority of his government, combat terrorism, and implement economic reforms.  However, he has been criticized for his inability to resolve political problems and bring peace to Yemen. 

Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi has continued to be the President of Yemen to this day, although he continues to face major political, military, and economic challenges.
Sushil Koirala:
Sushil Koirala was a prominent politician in Nepal and the Prime Minister of the country from March 2014 to September 2015.  He was born on August 12, 1938, into a political family.  Koirala was a member of the influential Koirala family, which has had a significant impact on Nepalese politics. 

Koirala began his involvement in politics in the 1950s as a young man.  He was a founding member of the Nepali Congress, the main opposition party in Nepal.  For many years, Koirala strove to fight for democracy and to eliminate the monarchy's rule in Nepal. 

Koirala was a well-known politician and one of the top leaders of the Nepali Congress.  He frequently participated in elections and played a key role in parliamentary proceedings.  Additionally, he was known for his ability to resolve conflicts within Nepal's politics. 

Mr.  Koirala gained more popularity when he was elected as the Prime Minister of Nepal after the 2013 election.  He was the first leader of the Nepali Congress to be appointed as Prime Minister in over 20 years.  During his tenure, Koirala worked to bridge ethnic and religious divides that have hindered Nepal's development. 

Apart from politics, Koirala was known for his ethics and generosity.  He was a hard worker and lived a modest life, always willing to help those in need.  After becoming Prime Minister, he addressed various issues such as constitutional amendments and economic development. 

Koirala passed away on February 9, 2016, at the age of 78.  His death was caused by heart problems.  He left behind a legacy of a strong and hardworking politician who fought for the development and democracy in Nepal.
Vladimir Putin:
Vladimir Putin is a Russian politician and the Leader of that country.  He was born on October 7, 1952 in Leningrad, Russia (now St.  Petersburg, Russia).  After working as a national security officer for several years, Putin began his political career in 1991. 

Putin quickly rose through the ranks in Russian politics.  After holding various government positions, including serving as a minister in the Russian government under President Boris Yeltsin, he was appointed as the Prime Minister of Russia in 1999.  Shortly after, Yeltsin appointed Putin as the acting President of Russia in December 1999, before Putin won the presidential election in 2000. 

Putin was re-elected as the President of Russia in the elections of 2004 and 2012, and his last term as president was between 2012 and 2018.  During this time, he made significant changes in Russian politics and governance, strengthening government control in various aspects of public life and sparking a significant debate on democracy and human rights in the country. 

Putin has often been criticized by the international community for restricting human rights, lack of freedom of the press, and Russia's interference in foreign affairs, particularly in the Ukraine conflict and partnerships with countries like Syria and Venezuela.  However, he remains highly popular in Russia, where he is known as a powerful leader representing the interests of the nation. 

Putin's political prowess has brought him great popularity and wealth, with estimated assets of around $70 billion.  He continues to be a significant figure in domestic and international politics, despite reaching the term limits as President of Russia.  Putin has been the chairman of the Security Council of Russia since April 2021, emphasizing his leadership position in the government.
Joachim Gauck:
Joachim Gauck is a German politician and human rights activist.  He was born on March 24, 1940, in Rostock, Germany. 

As the child of opponents of the Nazi regime, Gauck grew up in a political and social context that encouraged freedom of expression and democratic values.  This greatly influenced his life and contributed to his dedication to politics and human rights. 

After completing his higher education at the University of Jena, Gauck worked as a social investigator in the German Democratic Republic (GDR) from 1965 to 1990.  He was a human rights advocate in the GDR, investigating human rights violations, political abuses, and exposing truths that the GDR government tried to conceal. 

After the fall of the Berlin Wall and the reunification of Germany in 1990, Gauck was appointed as the interim commissioner for the Archive of the Stasi Records - the intelligence agency of the GDR.  Through this role, he played a key part in revealing the crimes committed by the Stasi and in helping Germans unite and start anew. 

In 2012, Gauck was elected as the President of Germany.  As president, he was known for his speeches and non-partisan stances, criticizing government abuses and emphasizing the importance of freedom, human rights, and democracy.  He led his country for five years before retiring in 2017. 

Joachim Gauck is known as a courageous individual and advocate for freedom and human rights.  He has dedicated himself in his work to strengthening people's belief in democracy and raising awareness about the importance of freedom and human dignity.
David Cameron:
David Cameron was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 2010 to 2016.  He was born on October 9, 1966 in London, United Kingdom.  He was the second child in his family and attended Eton College before studying Philosophy, Politics, and Economics at the University of Oxford. 

After graduating, Cameron worked in UK politics, serving under Chancellor Norman Lamont and Michael Howard.  He entered the UK Parliament in 2001 as the MP for Chipping Norton and quickly rose through the ranks in the Conservative Party. 

In 2005, Cameron was appointed as the leader of the Conservative Party and became the Leader of the Opposition.  He had goals of reforming his party and restoring its popularity, making significant efforts to change the perception of the party from the era of Thatcher and Major. 

In 2010, in the general election, Cameron led the Conservative Party to a strong performance, but did not secure enough seats to form a single-party government.  However, he successfully formed a coalition government with the Liberal Democrats and was appointed as the Prime Minister. 

As Prime Minister, Cameron faced many challenges, from the global economic crisis to the issue of Scottish independence and the UK's withdrawal from the European Union. Jacob Zuma:
