Zuma was the son of a common worker and grew up in poverty.  His education was only basic, and he dropped out of school at a young age to help his family.  Later, he joined the African National Congress (ANC) and fought against the apartheid regime. 

After spending ten years in prison as an ANC member, Zuma continued to be involved in politics and became one of the top leaders of the party.  He had extensive political experience and held various positions in the government, including serving as deputy president under Thabo Mbeki. 

Zuma began his presidential campaign in 2007 after defeating Mbeki in the ANC's internal election.  He took office in 2009 after the ANC won the general election, and served two terms as president. 

Zuma's leadership was plagued by corruption scandals and poor governance, leading the ANC to call for his resignation in 2018.  He faced charges of corruption and misappropriation of public funds, which remain unresolved. 

While his administration had some success in improving the country's economy and providing basic services such as education and healthcare to a large number of people, Zuma was seen by many as a leader who failed to address the major problems facing the country. 

Jacob Zuma continues to have significant influence in South African politics and remains involved in ANC affairs.  However, his reputation has greatly diminished since leaving office, and he still faces various legal charges.
Uhuru Kenyatta:
Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta is a Kenyan politician and the current president of the country.  He was born on October 26, 1961, in Nairobi, Kenya, and is the first child of Kenya's first president, Jomo Kenyatta, and Mama Ngina Kenyatta. 

Uhuru Kenyatta received his primary education at St.  Mary's School in Nairobi.  He later attended St.  Mary's High School in Rift Valley and completed his studies in 1979.  He proceeded to pursue university education at Amherst College in Massachusetts, USA, where he obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree in Economics in 1985. 

After graduating, Kenyatta returned to Kenya and ventured into business and investments.  He later founded several companies, including Heritage Hotels Limited, which owns and operates several hotels in Kenya. 

In politics, Uhuru Kenyatta started his involvement in the 1990s.  He was one of the founding members of the Jubilee Party of Kenya in 2016 and has held various leadership positions, including Minister of Tourism, Minister of Finance, and Deputy Prime Minister.  In 2013, he won the presidential election and has served two terms in office since then. 

Uhuru Kenyatta has been President of Kenya for a significant part of his tenure, striving to bring about economic and social development.  He has made efforts to reduce poverty, improve infrastructure, and create employment.  He has also been successful in enhancing national security and maintaining peace. 

Kenyatta has been internationally recognized for his contributions to advocating for African issues and has held various leadership positions in the African and international community.  He has also been involved in peace talks and dialogues in the East African region, including participating in seeking solutions to various conflicts in the area. 

Despite facing several challenges during his presidency, Kenyatta remains a key figure in Kenyan and African politics overall.
Yoweri Museveni:
Yoweri Museveni is a politician and the current president of Uganda.  He was born on September 15, 1944 in Rwakitura, Kiruhura District, Uganda.  Museveni received his early education at Rwakitura Primary School and later at Ntare School in Mbarara. 

Museveni began his involvement in politics during his university years when he joined the Front for National Salvation (Fronasa), a rebel group fighting against the governments of Idi Amin and later Milton Obote.  After the overthrow of Obote's government, Museveni helped establish the National Resistance Movement (NRM), which waged a bush war against the government of Tito Okello.  The war ended in 1986 and Museveni became the President of Uganda. 

Museveni has been in power for over 30 years now and has won several elections since then.  His supporters praise his leadership in bringing stability and development to the country.  He has been able to reduce poverty levels and improve essential services such as education and healthcare. 

However, there have also been criticisms of his rule.  Museveni has been criticized for violating democracy and undermining civil and political rights.  He has faced allegations of weakening the opposition and controlling the media.  Additionally, there are questions about his long tenure in office and whether the nation needs new leadership and change. 

Despite these challenges, Yoweri Museveni remains one of the longest-serving presidents in Africa.  He has declared himself a spokesperson for Africa's interests and has continued to engage in regional and international affairs.
Abdelaziz Bouteflika:
Abdelaziz Bouteflika is a prominent politician from Algeria.  He was born on March 2, 1937 in Oujda, Morocco, and later moved to Algeria with his family. 

Bouteflika joined the Algerian liberation movement when he was young and took part in the fight against French colonialism.  After Algeria gained independence in 1962, Bouteflika was appointed Minister of Youth, Sports, and Culture at the age of just 26.  He held various government positions and served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1963 to 1979. 

Bouteflika also served as the Prime Minister of Algeria from 1979 to 1981.  However, the peak of his popularity came when he was elected President of Algeria in 1999.  He was appointed after many years of being out of the political scene due to health reasons. 

Bouteflika led the country for a long time and made many changes aimed at improving the economy and the lives of the Algerian people.  He was able to manage the restoration of peace and stability after many years of civil war in the country.  He emphasized a policy of political stability and building good relations with other African countries and the world in general. 

However, his rule was plagued by allegations of corruption and a unique grip on power.  He was also accused of stifling democratic elections and undermining press freedom.  Furthermore, he was criticized for allowing himself to be reelected four times without holding free and fair elections. 

In April 2019, Bouteflika was forced to resign from the presidency after large public protests against his rule, which demanded major political changes and his departure from power.  He announced that he would not seek a fifth term, but there were many questions about his eligibility due to his health condition.
Omar al-Bashir:
Omar Hassan al-Bashir al-Mahdi is a politician from Sudan who was born on January 1, 1944, in Hosh Bannaga, Sudan.  He served as the President of Sudan from 1989 until he was ousted in April 2019 following public protests. 

Al-Bashir began his military career in the 1960s and was a member of the First Sudanese Children's Movement.  After holding various military positions, he took part in a military coup in 1989 and became the President of Sudan.  He was elected in the general elections in 1996 and 2010, but these elections raised many suspicions from his opponents and the international community. 

Al-Bashir's rule was marked by controversy, with allegations of gross human rights violations, genocide, and crimes against humanity in the Darfur region.  He was also accused of large-scale corruption and crackdown on freedom of expression. 

In 2009, the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for him on charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity.  However, the Sudanese government refused to implement the order. 

In 2019, public protests in Sudan successfully removed al-Bashir from power after his 30-year rule.  After being ousted, al-Bashir was arrested and faced several charges by the Sudanese government, including plotting to overthrow the government and corruption.  In 2020, al-Bashir was found guilty of corruption and sentenced to two years in prison. 

Omar al-Bashir is widely recognized as a ruthless dictator and oppressor in Sudan's history.  His rule had a significant impact on the political, economic, and social development of Sudan.
Abdelilah Benkirane:
Abdelilah Benkirane is a prominent Moroccan politician who was born on April 16, 1954 in Rabat, Morocco.  He is the leader of the Party of Justice and Development (PJD) in the country. 

Benkirane studied at Mohammed V University in Rabat, where he obtained his first degree in Law.  Later, he also studied at the Rabat Law School, where he obtained a Master's degree in Human Rights. 

At the beginning of his career, Benkirane worked in the education sector and was a teacher of law and history at a high school.  He later became a teacher and researcher at Mohammed V University. 

In the 1990s, Benkirane began to be more involved in politics.  He joined the Party of Justice and Development (PJD), which was an Islamic party, and became a prominent member.  In 2004, he was appointed as the Secretary General of the party. 

In 2011, Benkirane won the election and became the first Prime Minister of Morocco from an Islamic party.  He led a coalition government with a religious orientation that aimed to strengthen democracy in Morocco. 

Benkirane led the coalition government for two consecutive terms, from 2011 to 2017.  During his leadership, he strove to implement significant changes in the country, including reforms in the education sector, fighting corruption, and promoting economic development. 

However, his government faced several challenges, including opposition from other political parties and civil society groups.  There were also concerns about freedom of expression and human rights under his leadership. 

After completing his two terms as Prime Minister in 2017, Benkirane decided not to seek leadership of the government again.  However, he continues to be a respected politician and senior member of the PJD. 

Overall, Abdelilah Benkirane has been a mediator and national leader in Morocco.  He has worked to make positive changes and improve the economic and political situation in the country, although some of his actions have been controversial and sparked debate.
Jos\u00e9 Eduardo dos Santos:
José Eduardo dos Santos was a politician from Angola who served as the President of the country for 38 years, from 1979 to 2017.  He was born on August 28, 1942 in Luanda, Angola. 

Dos Santos was a member of the MPLA (People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola) party since the 1960s.  He joined the party during the Portuguese colonial rule in Angola, where he lived in exile in Tanzania and Guinea-Bissau receiving military and political training. 

After Angola gained independence in 1975, Dos Santos was appointed as the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Vice President, and then succeeded the first President of Angola, Agostinho Neto, after his death in 1979. 

During his leadership, Dos Santos guided the country through the Angolan Civil War, which ended in 2002.  He implemented several political and economic reforms, including economic reforms to stimulate the country's growth and development. 

However, Dos Santos was criticized by opponents for what they claimed was oppressive rule and corruption.  He was also blamed for failing to address significant disparities in the distribution of wealth in Angola.  His family was alleged to have significant influence in the country and to own the country's assets and resources. 

In 2017, Dos Santos decided not to run for re-election and appointed João Lourenço, a member of the MPLA party, to succeed him.  This was a surprising and notable move for many, which was seen as an attempt to continue his rule behind the scenes and maintain his influence. 

José Eduardo dos Santos has retired from politics and now lives a private life.  He leaves behind a significant legacy in the history of Angola, and his rule will remain a topic of debate regarding its effects on the country and its people.
Filipe Nyusi:
Filipe Jacinto Nyusi is a Mozambican politician who has served as the President of the country since 2015.  He was born on February 9, 1959 in the town of Namau, Mueda district, Cabo Delgado province, in northern Mozambique. 

Nyusi received his primary and secondary education in various parts of Mozambique before attending Eduardo Mondlane University in Maputo.  There, he studied civil engineering and graduated in 1981. 

After graduating, Nyusi joined the FRELIMO Party, which leads Mozambique.  He was heavily involved in the liberation movement of Mozambique from Portuguese colonial rule.  Later, he underwent military training in various countries, including East Germany. 

Nyusi began his official political career in the Mozambican government after independence in 1975.  He served as an assistant to President Samora Machel and also as the head of several districts in the country.  He advanced politically and held various positions in the government and the party, including serving as the Minister of Defense from 2008 to 2014. 

In 2014, Filipe Nyusi won the presidential election and officially began his term as President of Mozambique in January 2015.  Under his leadership, Nyusi has focused on economic development, poverty alleviation, and infrastructure development in the country. 

He is also attentive to security issues, as since taking office, Mozambique has been plagued by a wave of conflict and terrorism in the Cabo Delgado region. 

Filipe Nyusi has demonstrated strong leadership and is known for his efforts to develop Mozambique and fight for the well-being of its citizens.  He continues to be a key leader in Southern Africa and is working to strengthen relations with the international community.
John Mahama:
John Dramani Mahama was born on November 29, 1958, in Damongo, Ghana.  He is known by his political alias, John Mahama.  He is a Ghanaian politician and was the President of Ghana from July 2012 to January 2017. 

Mahama received his primary and secondary education in Ghana before attending the University of Ghana where he studied History.  Later, he studied economics and politics at the Moscow State University in Russia. 

After graduating, Mahama worked in the economics department of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and later became the Head of the Economics and Statistics Department at the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS). 

Mahama entered politics in 1996 when he was elected as the Member of Parliament for Bole-Bamboi and later appointed as the Deputy Minister of Transport.  In the government of President John Atta Mills, Mahama served as the Vice President from 2009 to 2012. 

After the death of President Mills in 2012, Mahama succeeded him as the President of Ghana.  He ran in the election of that year and won with 50. 7% of the vote.  He led the country for one term, attempting to bring about changes in the country's economy and fight against corruption. 

Under Mahama's leadership, Ghana made progress in energy, infrastructure, and education.  However, he faced several challenges including a decline in the country's economy, power crisis, and corruption scandals. 

In the 2016 general election, Mahama was defeated by Nana Akufo-Addo and he became the new President of Ghana.  He has continued to be involved in politics and plays a key role in the National Democratic Congress (NDC), which is the main opposition party in Ghana. 

John Mahama is recognized as a skilled, gentle, and dedicated politician in serving the people of Ghana.  He is a husband and father of five children.
Hery Rajaonarimampianina:
Hery Rajaonarimampianina is a Malagasy politician who served as the President of the country from 2014 to 2019.  He is known for his dedicated leadership and efforts to bring about economic development and change for the people of Madagascar. 

Hery Rajaonarimampianina was born on November 6, 1958, in the city of Antananarivo, Madagascar.  He had a childhood dream of studying civil engineering, and he succeeded in achieving his dream after graduating with a degree in civil engineering from the University of Madagascar in 1986. 

After graduating, Rajaonarimampianina worked as a civil engineer and later ventured into business.  He founded his construction consultancy company and built a good reputation for his innovative and quality work.  His experience in this field was instrumental in building Madagascar's economy and enabling infrastructure development. 

In 2009, Rajaonarimampianina was appointed as the Minister of Finance in the Madagascar government.  As a minister, he worked tirelessly to reform the country's economy and strengthen financial management.  His effective leadership led to his election as President of Madagascar in the 2013 election. 

During his presidency, Rajaonarimampianina prioritized economic growth, anti-corruption efforts, and improving infrastructure and public services.  He made changes in the energy, agriculture, and tourism sectors to attract investments and increase national revenue. 

Additionally, Rajaonarimampianina made efforts to promote international cooperation with other countries.  He led efforts to strengthen Madagascar's relations with other African countries and enhance diplomatic relations with Western countries. 

However, Rajaonarimampianina's leadership faced challenges, including large public protests against his rule over allegations of corruption and political crisis.  After his term in office ended, he left power in 2019. 

Overall, Hery Rajaonarimampianina was seen as a hardworking leader in promoting economic development and bringing change in Madagascar.  However, his performance sparked debate and differing opinions on the effectiveness and outcomes of his government.
Paul Biya:
Paul Biya is a politician from Cameroon who has served as the President of the country since 1982.  He was born on February 13, 1933, in the town of Mvomeka'a, in the southern region of Cameroon.  Biya received his higher education in France and later worked in international relations. 

Biya began his political career in the 1960s, working in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Cameroon.  Later, he served as the Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1975 to 1982.  In that year, he succeeded Ahmadou Ahidjo as the President of Cameroon after his retirement. 

Biya has been leading Cameroon longer than any other leader in the country's history.  He has been elected six times as President, in elections that have been questioned by opposition and the international community.  There are allegations of dictatorship, serious human rights violations, and violations of democracy under his rule. 

In domestic policies, Biya has faced many challenges including corruption, unemployment, poverty, and lack of press freedom.  His government is praised for infrastructure development and investment, although the benefits have not reached every citizen. 

On the international stage, Biya has been advocating for issues concerning African countries, especially in the Maldives and Western Sahara matters.  He has also participated in United Nations and African Union sessions, providing opinions and contributing to peace and development strategies in Africa. 

However, Biya has been frequently criticized for failing to address social, economic, and political challenges in Cameroon.  He has been accused of lacking solidarity with his citizens and promoting authoritarian rule.  There are also allegations of human rights violations and persecution against political opponents. 

Overall, Paul Biya remains a veteran leader in Cameroonian politics, targeted by a mix of opinions regarding his legacy and the impact of his rule on development and democracy in the country.
Alassane Ouattara:
Alassane Ouattara is a politician and a successful businessman from Ivory Coast.  He was born on January 1, 1942 in Dimbokro, Ivory Coast.  He served as the President of Ivory Coast from 2010 to 2020.  He has also held various leadership positions, including Minister of Finance, Governor of the Central Bank, and Prime Minister. 

Ouattara received his higher education in France, where he graduated with a degree in economics and business from the University of Dijon and a master's degree in economics from the University of Pennsylvania, USA.  Later, he earned a PhD in international economics from the University of Pennsylvania. 

After graduating, Ouattara worked at the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for several years, focusing on financial and economic issues.  He later returned to Ivory Coast and began working in the government. 

In 2010, after the presidential election in Ivory Coast led to a major political crisis, Ouattara was declared the winner by the international community.  However, the incumbent president at the time, Laurent Gbagbo, refused to accept defeat and his supporters sparked political violence.  After several months of unrest, Ouattara was able to assume power and take office as president. 

As president, Ouattara made significant efforts to strengthen Ivory Coast's economy and bring development to the country.  He implemented important reforms and economic policies that helped the country become one of the fastest growing economies in Africa.  He also placed a strong emphasis on strengthening the rule of law and combating corruption. 

However, Ouattara has also been criticized and blamed for causing political tensions and tribal conflicts in Ivory Coast.  After completing his two terms in office, Ouattara decided not to run for the presidency again in 2020 and instead nominated another candidate from his party. 

Alassane Ouattara is a prominent leader with significant influence in Ivorian and West African politics in general.  He is known as an economist and a restorer of the economic situation in Ivory Coast.
Mahamadou Issoufou:
Mahamadou Issoufou is a politician from Niger who was born on January 31, 1952.  He was the President of Niger from 2011 to 2021. 

Issoufou began his political career as a member of the Socialist Party of Niger (CNSN), which later transformed into the Nigerien Party for Democracy and Socialism (PNDS-Tarayya).  He was part of the opposition movement against the military government of Niger in the 1990s and gained significant popularity. 

In 1995, Mahamadou Issoufou helped establish and lead the PNDS-Tarayya and was its presidential candidate in the elections of 1993 and 1996.  He enjoyed substantial support from voters, but his elections were marred by controversy.  It took some time for Issoufou to accept the results, showcasing his leadership composure and patience. 

Utilizing his background as a mining engineer, Issoufou focused on policies to strengthen the mining sector and increase national income.  He oversaw the implementation of policies to enhance investment, improve infrastructure, and promote agricultural sector development. 

In April 2011, Issoufou won the presidential election and began his first official term.  He became the first president in Niger's history to voluntarily step down after completing his two terms in office. 

Issoufou faced numerous challenges during his leadership, including combating terrorism and fighting against Islamic groups affiliated with Al-Qaeda and ISIS.  He also tackled poverty and rampant corruption in Niger. 

After stepping down in April 2021, Mahamadou Issoufou handed over leadership to his close ally, Mohamed Bazoum.  He continues to be highly respected for his strong leadership and efforts in advancing Niger's development.
Michel Kafando:
Michel Kafando is a politician from Burkina Faso who was born on August 18, 1942 in Ouahigouya, a city in the north of the country.  He served as the transitional president of Burkina Faso from 2014 to 2015. 

Kafando was a professional diplomat and served as Burkina Faso's ambassador to several countries, including Morocco, Egypt, and Benin.  He also served as the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Burkina Faso. 

In October 2014, Kafando was appointed as the transitional president of Burkina Faso after the long-time president Blaise Compaoré was ousted.  Kafando led the transitional government aimed at restoring civilian rule and preparing the country for new elections. 

He played a crucial role in overseeing the political changes in Burkina Faso at that time, including holding talks with political parties, media outlets, and civil society organizations.  He also helped in organizing the general election that took place in November 2015. 

After completing his role as the transitional president, Kafando ran for president in Burkina Faso's general election in 2020, but did not succeed.  He has continued to contribute to the politics of Burkina Faso and to help bring stability and democracy to the country.
Ibrahim Boubacar Ke\u00efta:
Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, known as IBK, was the President of Mali from 2013 to 2020.  He was born on September 29, 1945, in Koutiala, Mali.  He joined political movements at a young age and began the liberation struggle against colonial rule. 

Keïta studied in France and obtained his first degree in history and geography.  He was a founding member of the Rally for Mali Party (RPM) in 2001 and served as the Prime Minister of Mali from 1994 to 2000 under President Alpha Oumar Konaré's administration. 

IBK lost the presidential elections in 2002 and 2007, but he won the presidential election in 2013.  He was elected on a promise to bring peace and stability to the country, especially after dealing with the northern Mali insurgency that began in 2012. 

During his presidency, Keïta worked to address security issues, economic development, and the fight against corruption.  However, his leadership was criticized for failing to end the suffering of ethnic violence and rebellion in northern Mali.  Additionally, his administration faced strong opposition from opposition groups, especially during public protests in 2020, which eventually led to his resignation. 

IBK resigned in August 2020 after a military coup.  Despite the decline in his popularity during his final leadership term, Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta will be remembered as the President of the country for seven years and as a significant figure in Mali's history.
Barack Obama:
Barack Hussein Obama II is an American politician who served as the 44th President of the United States from 2009 to 2017.  He was born on August 4, 1961, in Honolulu, Hawaii. 

Obama was raised by a Kenyan father and an American mother, and he was brought up in Hawaii and Indonesia.  He graduated from Columbia University in New York and later earned a Law degree from Harvard University.  After his studies, he lived in Chicago where he worked as a civil rights attorney and social activist. 

Obama rose to national prominence in 2004 when he spoke at the Democratic National Convention, delivering a powerful speech that gained him widespread popularity.  In 2008, he won the Democratic Party's nomination and became the first African-American presidential nominee in U. S.  history. 

In the 2008 general election, Obama defeated John McCain and became the first African-American President of the United States.  He gained popularity for his reform policies, including his commitment to addressing climate change and public health issues. 

As President, Obama served two terms and faced numerous economic, military, and political challenges.  He implemented the Affordable Care Act, which ensured access to quality healthcare for all Americans.  He also made efforts to reform immigration policy and improve relations between the U. S.  and foreign countries. 

His humility, communication skills, and vision for unity in America earned him worldwide acclaim.  In 2009, Obama was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in promoting peace and diplomacy in international politics. 

After completing his term in 2017, Obama has continued to have an impact on politics and society, working as a writer, speaker, and human rights activist.  He and his wife, Michelle Obama, have also established the Obama Foundation for Public Leadership and the Michelle Obama Girls' Education Initiative.
Dilma Rousseff:
Dilma Vana Rousseff was born on December 14, 1947 in Belo Horizonte, Minas Gerais, Brazil.  She was a Brazilian politician and a member of the Workers' Party (PT).  Dilma was the 36th president of Brazil from 2011 to 2016. 

Dilma was the first woman to become president of Brazil, serving for two terms.  She gained prominence as a human rights activist and as the energy minister in the government of former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. 

As president, Dilma was known for her social policies aimed at reducing social inequality and improving the lives of the poorest people in Brazil.  She was at the forefront of investing in education and healthcare, and establishing social programs, such as Bolsa Familia, which aimed to eradicate poverty. 

However, her administration faced many challenges, including a declining economy in Brazil and corruption scandals.  In 2016, Dilma was suspended by the Brazilian Congress on allegations of misusing government budgets and causing a significant financial deficit.  She was charged with breaking Brazil's budget laws. 

Dilma was formally removed from office on August 31, 2016 after an impeachment trial.  She continued to challenge the decision and claimed to be a victim of political conspiracy. 

After being removed from office, Dilma has been involved in international affairs, engaging with other world leaders on issues of human rights, democracy, and sustainable development. 

Overall, Dilma Rousseff has been a significant figure in the history of Brazil, participating in political movements and bringing about social changes in the country.
Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto:
Enrique Peña Nieto is a Mexican politician who served as the president of Mexico from 2012 to 2018.  He was born on July 20, 1966, in Atlacomulco, Mexico. 

Peña Nieto began his political career in the 1980s as a member of the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI).  He rose through the ranks of the party and eventually was elected as the governor of the State of Mexico, a populous state in Mexico. 

Peña Nieto's presidency was marked by challenges and controversies.  During his tenure, he faced various contentious issues including rising crime rates, corruption, and significant opposition from citizens who protested against his economic policies. 

On the economic front, Peña Nieto oversaw several key reforms, including energy sector reform and education reform.  However, critics argue that these reforms did not yield significant results and primarily benefited the elite rather than the ordinary citizens. 

In his political leadership, Peña Nieto also faced several corruption scandals and human rights violations.  Opposition against him was strong, leading to nationwide protests. 

After completing his term as president, Peña Nieto withdrew from politics and has since kept a low profile politically.  He has continued to work in the private sector and has been involved in non-political international activities.
Juan Manuel Santos:
Juan Manuel Santos is a Colombian politician who served as the President of the country from 2010 to 2018.  He was born on August 10, 1951 in Bogota, Colombia. 

Santos studied economics and business at the University of Kansas in the United States, and also served in the Colombian Air Force.  Later, he studied government and economic development at Harvard University. 

Before entering politics, Santos was a journalist and political analyst.  He joined the newspaper El Tiempo where he worked as editor of the political analysis section and briefly served as the chief editor of the newspaper. 

Santos entered politics in 1991 when he was elected as a member of the Colombian Congress.  He held various leadership positions, including Minister of Trade, Minister of Finance, and Minister of Defense. 

One of Santos' major achievements was initiating peace talks with the rebel group Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC).  In 2016, a peace agreement was signed between the Colombian government and FARC, and Santos was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts in bringing peace to the country. 

Santos was the second president of the country to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize, following in the footsteps of former Colombian President, Juan Manuel Santos.  He also received international recognition for his leadership and implemented many economic development policies that helped reduce poverty. 

After leaving office, Santos continued to be involved in international affairs and has been working as a Special Envoy of the United Nations on the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar. 

Juan Manuel Santos is a politician dedicated to the development and peace of Colombia.  While he is seen as a successful leader, he has also faced challenges and opposition within his country due to his policies.
Cristina Fern\u00e1ndez de Kirchner:
Cristina Fernández de Kirchner is a prominent Argentine politician and was the president of the country from 2007 to 2015.  She was born on February 19, 1953 in La Plata, the capital city of the Buenos Aires province. 

Cristina's family had a political background, with her father being an advocate for political participation.  She joined the Peronist party while still a university student and continued her political activities after graduation. 

Cristina gained national prominence when she was elected as a national senator for the province of Santa Cruz in 1995 and later became the president of the Senate in 2005.  She later ran for president in 2007 and won the election by receiving 45% of the votes. 

During her tenure, Cristina was known for her socialist policies and social reforms.  She implemented social inclusion policies that reduced poverty and emphasized issues of health and education.  She also focused on foreign policy and forged trade partnerships with other countries, especially China. 

However, there have also been allegations of corruption and misconduct against her and her government, and even after leaving office, Cristina has faced several corruption charges and abuse of power accusations.  Nevertheless, she continues to be a prominent politician with great popularity in Argentina. 

Cristina Fernández de Kirchner is a strong and wise woman who has remained influential in Argentine politics.  Despite facing challenges and allegations, she continues to have significant influence in the politics of her country.
Justin Trudeau:
Justin Trudeau is a politician from Canada who has served as the Prime Minister of the country since 2015.  He was the leader of the Liberal Party, a progressive and socialist party in the country. 

Justin Trudeau was born on December 25, 1971 in Ottawa, Canada.  He is the son of former Canadian Prime Minister, Pierre Trudeau, who also served as the leader of the Liberal Party.  He studied Arts and Education Sciences at McGill University and later obtained a Master's degree in International Economics from the London School of Economics. 

Following the 2015 election, the Liberal Party, under Trudeau's leadership, emerged victorious and he became the first French-Canadian Prime Minister in the country since the 1970s.  He continued to serve as Prime Minister after winning the general election again in 2019. 

Trudeau has had a center-left stance in his policies, supporting issues such as gender equality, climate change, and increasing public spending on healthcare and education.  He has also maintained a generous immigration policy, welcoming refugees and immigrants to Canada. 

During his leadership, Trudeau has taken cautious steps to address economic and political challenges in Canada.  He has made efforts to strengthen Canada's relations with other countries, advocating for sustainable development and international cooperation. 

However, there are critics who have raised concerns such as corruption scandals and allegations of lack of transparency in his leadership.  This has led to a decline in his popularity and an increase in opposition against his administration. 

Overall, Justin Trudeau has been known as a leader with a belief in sustainable development, and he has sought to achieve his goals through socialist policies.  However, he will be remembered for addressing the difficult political and economic challenges in Canada, and continuing to be one of the top leaders in international politics.
Ollanta Humala:
Ollanta Humala Tasso is a politician from Peru who was born on June 27, 1962 in Lima, Peru.  He was the President of Peru from 2011 to 2016. 

Humala received his university education in Armada de Perú, a naval tank training school, where he graduated as a Lieutenant.  Later, he studied political science at the University of Peru, where he earned his bachelor's degree. 

Humala became well-known as a soldier in the Peruvian army.  He was a participant in the failed coup attempt of 2000 against President Alberto Fujimori.  The attempt was unsuccessful, and Humala was arrested and imprisoned for a period. 

After being released, Humala decided to enter politics and founded a political party called Gana Peru (Nationalist Party of Peru).  He ran for the presidency of Peru twice.  In his first election in 2006, he made it to the second round but was defeated by Alan Garcia.  However, in the second election in 2011, he won and became the President of Peru. 

As President, Humala prioritized improving the living conditions of many poor Peruvians.  He implemented policies to enhance employment, education, social services, and human rights.  He also had a strong stance on protecting Peru's natural resources and preventing environmental damage. 

Humala led Peru until the end of his term in 2016.  After leaving office, he has continued to be active in politics and has been involved in regional and international issues. 

Overall, Ollanta Humala is a dedicated politician in the fight against poverty and in improving the lives of all Peruvians.  He has played a significant role in Peruvian politics and is considered a leader who has brought about change in the country.
Nicol\u00e1s Maduro:
Nicolás Maduro is a Venezuelan politician who was born on November 23, 1962, in Caracas, Venezuela.  He was originally employed as a bus driver before getting involved in politics. 

Maduro began to be known in politics as a young man, supporting the socialist party of the Movement for the Fifth Republic (MVR) led by Hugo Chávez.  He impressed Chávez and was appointed as his security and communication advisor.  After Chávez was elected as president of Venezuela in 1998, Maduro was given higher responsibilities in the government. 

After the death of his leader, Chávez, in 2013, Maduro was appointed as his successor and was elected as president on April 14, 2013.  He has been the president of Venezuela since then, continuing Chávez's socialist policies and the "Bolivarian Revolution" policy. 

Maduro's administration has been highly controversial.  His opponents have accused him of political repression, corruption, and serious violations of human rights.  In 2019, Juan Guaidó declared himself as the interim president of Venezuela, emphasizing the failure of Maduro's 2018 election. 

Maduro has faced significant pressure from the international community, and several countries, including the United States, have recognized Guaidó as the legitimate leader of Venezuela.  However, Maduro still holds onto power and is supported by countries like Russia and China. 

Nicolás Maduro has had a significant impact on Venezuela's domestic and foreign policies.  Despite widespread criticism, he continues to be the president of the country and seems likely to remain in power for a long time.
Michelle Bachelet:
Michelle Bachelet is a politician from Chile and a human rights activist.  She was born on September 29, 1951 in Santiago, Chile.  Bachelet has served as the President of Chile twice, first from 2006 to 2010, and again from 2014 to 2018. 

Bachelet grew up in a political family, as her father, Alberto Bachelet, was a general in the Chilean military.  However, her family suffered during the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet.  Her father lost his life in military custody, and Bachelet and her mother were imprisoned and tortured. 

After being released, Bachelet joined the Socialist Party in Chile.  She specialized in health issues and was awarded a doctorate in pediatric medicine. 

In 2002, Bachelet was appointed as the Minister of Health and worked hard to address the challenges within the healthcare system in Chile.  Her success led her to be given another important role, as the Minister of Defense of Chile in 2002.  This was the first time a woman had held the position of Minister of Defense in Chile, and in all of South America. 

Bachelet was elected as President of Chile for the first time in January 2006.  She pushed for reforms in education and healthcare, and placed emphasis on addressing social issues and human rights.  Her establishment of the United Nations Human Rights Council also enhanced Chile's reputation on the international stage. 

After completing her first term, Bachelet was appointed as the Executive Director of UN Women.  She served in that role from 2010 to 2013, advocating for gender equality and women's rights worldwide. 

In 2014, Bachelet returned to Chilean politics and was elected as President for a second term.  During her second term, she continued to work on improving healthcare services, expanding social security systems, and addressing corruption and inequality. 

Under Bachelet's leadership, Chile made significant progress in many areas, including reducing poverty and crime.  However, she faced challenges related to large-scale student and citizen protests demanding further political and social reforms. 

After completing her second term in 2018, Bachelet was appointed as the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.  In this role, she oversees human rights issues globally and advocates for the protection and promotion of human rights for all people. 

Michelle Bachelet is known as a brave politician, a human rights activist, and a champion for women.  She continues to be a vital voice on the international stage on issues of human rights, gender equality, and social development.
Otto P\u00e9rez Molina:
Otto Pérez Molina was the President of Guatemala from 2012 to 2015.  He was born on November 1, 1950, in Guatemala City, Guatemala.  Molina served in the Guatemalan army for many years and was a general in the army before entering politics. 

Pérez Molina gained prominence during the Guatemalan Civil War in the 1980s.  He was involved in military operations during the war and gained a reputation for being tough and having significant military influence.  After the war, he helped establish the political party Partido Patriota (Patriotic Party), which advocated for security and rule of law issues in Guatemala. 

In 2011, Molina ran for president and won the election.  He took office on January 14, 2012.  As President, Molina promised to fight corruption and improve security in the country.  However, his administration was marred by numerous corruption scandals. 

In September 2015, Molina resigned after a corruption case revealed his involvement in a customs revenue fraud scandal.  After resigning, Molina was arrested and imprisoned.  In August 2018, he was called to court for more corruption charges and is awaiting trial.
Rafael Correa:
Rafael Correa Delgado is a prominent Ecuadorian politician.  He was born on April 6, 1963, in Guayaquil, Ecuador.  He served as the president of Ecuador from 2007 to 2017. 

Correa received his primary education at Salesiano School in Guayaquil and then went on to study economics at the Catholic University of Ecuador.  Later, he pursued further studies in economics and history at the University of Louvain in Belgium, where he obtained his master's degree in economics.  He continued his studies and earned a master's degree in business education and management from the University of Illinois in the United States. 

Before entering politics, Correa worked in various international institutions such as the World Bank and the World Trade Organization (WTO).  He also served as a visiting professor at the Catholic University of Ecuador and the Andean University. 

Correa entered politics in 2005 when he founded the LEFT Revolutionary Country (Alianza PAIS) party.  He was nominated as the presidential candidate in the 2006 election and won, becoming the president of Ecuador in January 2007.  During his presidency, he implemented strong political and economic measures, leading social and economic reforms known as the Citizen Revolution. 

Under Correa's leadership, Ecuador experienced economic development and a reduction in social inequality.  His government increased investments in infrastructure and public services, improved education, healthcare, and social welfare.  Correa also made reforms in the oil and mining sectors, increasing the government's share in oil production. 

However, his critics argue that he had an authoritarian approach, restricted freedom of expression, oppressed opponents, and weakened democracy.  After a decade in power, Correa announced that he would not run for president again and handed over power to his successor, Lenín Moreno, in May 2017. 

Overall, Rafael Correa Delgado has been a powerful and popular politician in Ecuador, leading a strong government and implementing significant reforms in the country.
Evo Morales:
Evo Morales Ayma was a South American progressive politician and the President of Bolivia from 2006 to 2019.  He was born on October 26, 1959 in Isallavi, Bolivia. 

Morales was the son of farmers and grew up in poverty.  He joined social movements of farmers as a young man, participating in protests and strikes of farmers.  This led him to engage in Bolivia's Socialist Farmer Movement (MAS) and eventually become its leader. 

Morales began his political career as a congressman in 1997, entering the Bolivian Congress.  He used this platform to advocate for and represent farmers and the poor, addressing issues such as land, farmer rights, and racial discrimination.  Among his main agendas were improving the lives of the poor and initiating political, economic, and social reforms. 

In December 2005, Morales won the presidential election and became the first indigenous president of Bolivia.  He served as the country's president for three consecutive terms.  His administration was known for implementing significant social and economic reforms.  He initiated land reforms by returning land to poor farmers and reducing foreign ownership of land and country resources. 

He also placed a strong emphasis on the energy sector, taking control of energy resources and contributing to economic growth.  He also made efforts to reduce poverty and create job opportunities through social programs and increasing investments in education and healthcare. 

However, his administration faced challenges and controversies.  There were allegations of corruption and abuse of power.  In the 2019 general election, there were allegations of fraud, and Morales declared himself the winner.  Following large protests and pressure, he resigned and sought exile in Mexico. 

Evo Morales has been one of the most influential leaders in South America, leading the wave of socialist movements in the region.  Although his administration was marked by controversy and challenges, he remains an icon of standing up against the oppression of the vulnerable and representing the poor and indigenous communities.
Michel Martelly:
Michel Martelly is a politician and a popular musician from Haiti.  He was born on February 12, 1961 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.  He served as the President of Haiti from 2011 to 2016.  He gained great popularity under the stage name "Sweet Micky" through his Konpas music. 

Martelly started his career as a musician in Konpas music, which is a blend of African and Caribbean music.  He achieved great success with his albums and songs that made him popular in Haiti and internationally. 

After retiring from the music industry, Martelly entered politics and became a prominent politician.  He joined the Rassemblement des Démocrates Nationaux Progressistes (RDNP) party and participated in the presidential election of 2010.  He successfully won the election and became the President of Haiti. 

Martelly was recognized as a president who made significant efforts to rebuild Haiti after the major earthquake of 2010.  He worked to improve infrastructure, healthcare, education, and the economy of the country.  However, he faced significant political and economic challenges during his leadership. 

In his personal life, Martelly is married and has four children.  After leaving office, he continued working in the music industry and promoting social projects in Haiti.  Martelly has continued to have a significant influence on the politics and culture of Haiti.
Ra\u00fal Castro:
Raúl Castro was a Cuban politician who was the leader of the country from 2008 to 2018.  He was born on June 3, 1931 in Birán, Cuba, and was the son of the late Ernesto 'Che' Guevara, a hero of the Cuban revolution. 

Raúl Castro received his primary and secondary education in government schools in Santiago de Cuba.  Later, he attended the University of Havana where he studied law.  During that time, he participated in the revolutionary movements against the dictator of Cuba at the time, Fulgencio Batista. 

After successfully overthrowing the Batista regime and declaring his brother, Fidel Castro, as the leader of the country in 1959, Raúl held various leadership positions.  He served as the Minister of Defense of Cuba, where he built a strong military and engaged in many international activities during that period. 

In 2006, after his brother Fidel fell ill and stepped down from power, Raúl Castro was appointed as the acting president.  And in 2008, he officially took over the presidency of Cuba.  During his leadership, Castro advocated for furthering the revolutionary policies and advancing socialist policies in the country. 

Raúl Castro made efforts to strengthen Cuba's relations with the United States, including opening doors to foreign investment and relaxing the country's economic laws.  He was also an advocate for lifting the economic sanctions imposed by the United States against Cuba. 

However, he was criticized for failing to bring about more changes in the country and for restricting democracy and freedom of expression.  Despite a few reform measures, Raúl Castro's government faced strong opposition from human rights activists and political opponents. 

After ruling for 10 years, Raúl Castro announced that he would step down from power in April 2018.  This was a significant step in the political transition process in Cuba.  Even after stepping down, Castro has continued to be involved in politics as a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cuba.
Danilo Medina:
Danilo Medina is a Dominican politician who served as the President of the country from 2012 to 2020.  He was born on November 10, 1951, in Arroyo Cano, Azua, Dominican Republic. 

Medina received his primary and secondary education in regular schools in his country.  Later, he enrolled at the Autonomous University of Santo Domingo, where he graduated with a bachelor's degree in economics in 1984. 

Medina began his political career in the 1970s and joined the Dominican Revolutionary Party (PRD).  He was a close associate of Juan Bosch, the founder of the party, and worked as his economic advisor. 

In 1996, Medina was appointed as the Minister of Economy and Development of the Dominican Republic under the administration of President Leonel Fernandez.  He played a key role in improving the country's economy and reducing poverty. 

In 2012, after unsuccessful attempts in the 2000 and 2004 elections, Medina succeeded in being elected as the President of the Dominican Republic.  He implemented several development policies and social programs, including improving healthcare, education, and infrastructure services. 

Medina was known for introducing a program to enhance public education in the country, which led to an increase in the number of children receiving education.  He also implemented policies to promote agriculture, tourism, and industries to boost the Dominican economy. 

However, Medina faced several scandals and was accused of misuse of power and corruption.  This situation led to numerous protests and strong opposition against his administration. 

After completing his two terms as president, Medina handed over power to Luis Abinader in August 2020.  He was one of the prominent and influential leaders in the history of the Dominican Republic, although his rule was overshadowed by controversy and a series of scandals.
Juan Orlando Hern\u00e1ndez:
Juan Orlando Hernández is a politician from Honduras who served as the President of the country from January 27, 2014, to January 27, 2022.  He was born on October 28, 1968, in the city of Gracias, Lempira. 

Juan Orlando Hernández had a higher education in law and worked as a lawyer before entering politics.  He served as a member of the Honduran parliament for two terms from 2002 to 2010. 

As president, Hernández fought to reduce the levels of crime and corruption in Honduras.  He implemented various strategies aimed at improving the security of citizens, including establishing special police units and strengthening international cooperation in combating drug trafficking. 

During his leadership, Hernández also tried to promote economic development in Honduras through financial reforms and investments in infrastructure.  However, his leadership was marred by controversy and allegations of corruption and human rights violations. 

In November 2021, Hernández was elected as the leader of the ruling party, Partido Nacional, despite his presidency term coming to an end.  However, he faced strong opposition due to allegations of fraud in the election. 

Juan Orlando Hernández is known for his conservative views and strong stance on security and immigration issues.  He has continued to advocate for tough policies against crime and has collaborated with the United States government in efforts to reduce the wave of migrants from Central America. 

Hernández completed his term as President of Honduras on January 27, 2022, after serving two consecutive terms.  He continues to hold significant influence in Honduran politics, and the future of his political career is still awaited.
Horacio Cartes:
Horacio Cartes is an entrepreneur and politician from Paraguay, who served as the President of Paraguay from August 2013 to August 2018.  He was born on July 5, 1956 in Asunción, Paraguay. 

Cartes began building his wealth in the tobacco business sector, which drives Paraguay's economy.  He founded a tobacco company, "Tabacalera del Este," which enabled him to achieve significant financial success.  His success in business made him one of the wealthiest individuals in Paraguay. 

In addition to his business activities, Cartes was involved in Paraguayan politics.  He was a member of the Colorado Party, a long-standing conservative political party that ruled Paraguay for a long time.  He served as a senator in Paraguay from 2008 to 2013.  His presidency was the first time the country had a president who was not a member of a prominent political family. 

As President of Paraguay, Cartes worked to bring about economic and political changes in the country.  He promised to fight against corruption and strengthen the rule of law.  He also promoted foreign investment and the development of the agricultural sector, which is crucial to Paraguay's economy.  However, his leadership was marred by numerous scandals and strong opposition from the opposition. 

After completing his term as president in August 2018, Cartes intended to continue in politics and sought to run for a senatorial position.  However, Paraguay's Electoral Law prohibited former presidents from running for positions as lawmakers or senators.  Nevertheless, Cartes still wields significant influence in Paraguayan politics and continues to be a key figure in the business community. 

Overall, Horacio Cartes is a successful entrepreneur and politician from Paraguay, who has endeavored to lead economic and political changes in his country.  Despite his stance in politics, he remains a major force in Paraguayan politics.
Daniel Ortega:
Daniel Ortega Saavedra is a Nicaraguan politician who has been the president of the country since 2007.  He was born on November 11, 1945, in the city of La Libertad, Nicaragua. 

Ortega started his involvement in politics as a young man and was among the leaders of the Sandinista Revolution in the late 1970s.  This revolution overthrew the rule of dictator Anastasio Somoza, who had been leading the country in an oppressive and dictatorial manner for a long time. 

After the Sandinista Revolution, Ortega was appointed as the president of Nicaragua and led the country from 1985 to 1990.  During this time, he implemented reforms in the country, including establishing free health and education services for the citizens.  However, his rule faced political and economic crises, and he was defeated in the 1990 election by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. 

After years of opposition, Ortega regained power in the 2006 election and has been serving as president since then.  His administration has faced political challenges and his critics accuse him of further deteriorating democracy and freedom of expression in Nicaragua. 

During his second term in office, Ortega has continued to implement socialist policies, focusing on fighting poverty and improving the lives of ordinary people.  However, some critics claim that his rule suppresses opposition and undermines democracy. 

Daniel Ortega is a highly influential politician in Nicaragua, but assessments of his rule are divided.  His supporters praise him for his efforts to advocate for the interests of the marginalized and reduce the economic gap, but critics argue that he leads through repression and human rights violations.
Tony Abbott:
Tony Abbott is an Australian politician who served as the Prime Minister of Australia from 2013 to 2015.  He was born on November 4, 1957 in London, United Kingdom, but moved to Australia with his family as a child. 

Abbott entered politics in Australia in the 1990s as a representative of the Liberal Party of Australia.  From 2003 to 2007, he served as the Minister for Health and Ageing in the government of John Howard.  He also served as an advisor on domestic security and national security issues. 

Abbott gained popularity when he entered the leadership contest of the Liberal Party and won, making him the candidate for Prime Minister in the 2013 general election.  He was the 28th Prime Minister of Australia, serving from September 18, 2013 to September 15, 2015. 

As Prime Minister, Abbott was known for his economically and socially conservative policies.  He followed policies to reduce government spending and emphasized economic management.  He also held staunch views on immigration and refugee policies, implementing measures that led to the establishment of offshore refugee detention centers and tighter border controls. 

Abbott faced several challenges during his leadership, which led to a decline in his popularity.  He dealt with internal party conflicts and was criticized for his positions on climate change and gender issues. 

After being removed from office as Prime Minister in 2015, Abbott has continued to work as a member of parliament and has been involved in foreign policy and security matters.
John Key:
John Key is a New Zealand politician who served as the Prime Minister of the country from 2008 to 2016.  He was born on August 9, 1961 in Auckland, New Zealand. 

After completing his university studies, Key started his professional career in banking on Wall Street in New York.  He excelled in his work and eventually became the CEO of Merrill Lynch's Financial Sector. 

In 2001, Key decided to leave his banking career and ran for a parliamentary seat through the Conservative National Party.  He won the election and began his tenure as a member of parliament for the party.  Later, he became the Finance Minister of New Zealand under the leadership of Prime Minister Helen Clark. 

Despite his banking background, Key was able to build his popularity as a down-to-earth person who was involved in everyday issues.  He was recognized for his ability to work hard and put the interests of the New Zealand people first. 

As Prime Minister, Key implemented several policies that helped strengthen New Zealand's economy.  Some of his major achievements include controlling the national debt, advancing trade and investment policies, and promoting the tourism sector. 

Key stepped down as Prime Minister in December 2016, stating that he wanted to finish his work and spend more time with his family.  After leaving office, he has continued to be involved in both private and public activities.
